questions.question_text:
Your company has been running several small applications in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure and is planning a proof-of-concept (POC) to deploy Oracle PeopleSoft.
If your existing resources are being maintained in the root compartment, what is the recommended approach for defining security for the upcoming POC?

choices.A: Create a new compartment for the POC and grant appropriate permissions to create and manage resources within the compartment.
choices.D: Provision all new resources into the root compartment. Grant permissions that only allow for creation and management of resources specific to the POC.
choices.C: Provision all new resources into the root compartment. Use defined tags to separate resources that belong to different applications.
choices.B: Create a new tenancy for the POC and provision all new resources into the root compartment. Grant appropriate permissions to create and manage resources within the root compartment.

choices.A: Customer can encrypt the communication to a mount target via export options.
choices.C: File systems use Oracle-managed keys by default.
choices.B: Mount targets use Oracle-managed keys by default.
choices.D: Customer can encrypt data in their file system using their own Vault encryption key.
choices.E: Communication with file systems in a mount target is encrypted via HTTPS.

Selected Answer: CD
cf. https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Concepts/filestorageoverview.htm
"Encryption
==========
The File Storage service encrypts all file system and snapshot data at rest. By default all file systems are encrypted using Oracle-managed encryption keys. You have the option to encrypt all of your file systems using the keys that you own and manage using the Vault service. 

Note :
Currently, only symmetric Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) keys are supported for file system encryption."

questions.question_text: Which two statements about Oracle Cloud Infrastructure File Storage Service are accurate? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Users can be blocked but not deleted.
choices.D: User needs to be deleted from federation Identity Provider (IdP) before deleting from IAM.
choices.B: User is member of an Identity and Access Management (IAM) group.

questions.question_text:
An Oracle Cloud Infrastructure tenancy administrator is not able to delete a user in the tenancy.
What can cause this issue?

discussion.content:
Answer is B.
Prerequisite: To delete a user, the user must not be in any groups.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about Oracle Cloud Infrastructure storage services? (Choose two.)

choices.C: File Storage uses the network file system (NFS) protocol, whereas Block Volume uses iSCSI.
choices.A: You can take incremental snapshots of Block Volumes, File Storage file systems and Object Storage buckets.
choices.B: You can move Object Storage buckets, Block Volumes and File Storage mount targets between compartments.
choices.D: Block Volume service scales to Exabytes per instance, while File Storage service offers unlimited scalability.
choices.E: File storage mount target does not provide a private IP address, while the Object Storage bucket provides one.
